claim.text: Alexander, in Pattern 57 (Children in the City), argued that children need access to the whole city, not just designated play areas
claim.claim: Christopher Alexander's Pattern 57 in A Pattern Language is titled 'Children in the City' and argues children need access to the whole city, not just designated play areas

results.summary: Pattern 57 in A Pattern Language is correctly titled 'Children in the City' and argues children need access throughout the city, not just playgrounds.
results.detail: Christopher Alexander's Pattern 57 'Children in the City' in A Pattern Language (1977) argues that children are harmed when relegated only to playgrounds and designated areas, and instead need presence and access throughout the urban environment - on streets, in shops, in workplaces. The claim accurately represents both the pattern title and its core argument that children need 'access to the whole city, not just designated play areas.'
sources: Christopher Alexander, Sara Ishikawa, and Murray Silverstein, 'A Pattern Language: Towns, Buildings, Construction' (1977), Pattern 57
